hotspots.label: Bubble Surface
hotspots.fact: This bubble is made of soap and water, which are both types of matter. The thin film you see is so delicate that it can pop with just a tiny touch! This shows us how matter can change forms and how physical properties like thickness affect how fragile something is.

vocabulary.definition: Anything that takes up space and has weight, like solids, liquids, and gases.

hotspots.label: Light Reflecting
hotspots.fact: You can see rainbow colors on the bubble because light is bouncing off the soap film in different ways. This is a physical property called reflection, and it happens when light bounces off a surface. The different colors show us how light bends and reflects differently!

vocabulary.definition: When light bounces off a surface, like a mirror or a bubble, instead of passing through it.

hotspots.label: Curved Shape
hotspots.fact: Bubbles are always round because the water and soap stretch equally in all directions, creating the most balanced shape possible. This curved surface is a physical property of bubbles that helps them float and move through the air with ease.

vocabulary.definition: A characteristic of matter that you can observe or measure without changing what the material is, like shape, color, or size.

hotspots.label: Transparent Film
hotspots.fact: You can see through the bubble's thin soap film, which means it's transparent. This shows how different materials have different physical propertiesâ€”some let light pass through them while others don't. The thinness of the soap film makes it see-through and very delicate.

vocabulary.definition: When something is clear enough that you can see right through it, like glass or the bubble film.
